Adult C57BL/6 mice were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbitol (Nembutol) delivered by intraperitoneal injection. Animals were perfused transcardially with 20 ml of 4% formaldehyde in 86 mm NaPO4, pH 7.3. Eyes were removed and incised at the limbus to facilitate rapid fixation of the retina. After 10 min in fixative, the anterior segments and lenses were dissected from the eyes, and the eye cups were returned to the fixative. Eyes were immersed in 4% formaldehyde in 86 mm NaPO4, pH 7.3, for 4 h on ice. Residual aldehydes were removed by washing eye cups repeatedly in 137 mm NaPO4, pH 7.3 (3 × 20 min). Retinal tissue was prepared for confocal immunofluorescence labeling according to Hale and Matsumoto (22.Hale I., L. Matsumoto B. Methods Cell Biol. 1993; 38: 289-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Briefly, eye cups or peeled retinas were embedded in disposable weigh-boats containing molten low gel temperature agarose (5%) (Sigma) in phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.05% sodium azide at ∼40 °C. Agarose was solidified on ice for 1 h. Agarose blocks containing retinal tissue were trimmed and attached to metal stubs with cyanoacrylate adhesive. A Leica vibrating microtome was used to cut 100-μm sections of tissue, which were transferred to phosphate-buffered saline prior to immunolabeling. To reduce nonspecific labeling, retinal sections were incubated for 1 h in ICC buffer (phosphate-buffered saline, 0.5% bovine serum albumin, 0.5% Triton X-100, 0.01% sodium azide, pH 7.3), containing 5% normal goat serum. Sera from rabbits used for CaBP antibody production were diluted in ICC buffer as follows: UW72/CaBP1, 1:200; UW89/CaBP5, 1:400. Sections were incubated in primary antibody for 12 h at 4 °C. A monoclonal antibody to PKC (MC5 clone, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was diluted 1:50 and used for double-labeling studies to identify rod bipolar cells. Sections were then washed repeatedly in ICC buffer (3 × 20 min/1 × 60 min). Sections were incubated for 4 h in Cy3-conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibody (Jackson ImmunoResearch, West Grove, PA) diluted 1:200 in ICC buffer and subsequently washed in ICC buffer 3 × 20 min and 1 × 60 min. Sections were coverslipped in 50 μl of 5% n-propyl gallate in glycerol to retard photobleaching. Sections were analyzed and images collected using a Bio-Rad 600 laser scanning confocal microscope located at the W. M. Keck Center for Advanced Studies of Neural Signaling (University of Washington School of Medicine). Negative controls for immunolabeling studies included each of the following steps: omission of primary antibody; incubation in preimmune sera at matching dilutions from rabbits used for polyclonal production; and adsorbed controls using purified CaBP1 (for UW72) or CaBP5 (UW89) (600 nmfinal concentration) to abolish immunolabeling. The protein concentration was determined by the Bradford method (23.Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (216440) Google Scholar). SDS-PAGE was performed according to Laemmli (24.

Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is produced in pancreatic mesenchyme-derived cells and in islet cells. In vitro, HGF increases the insulin content and proliferation of islets. To study the role of HGF in the islet in vivo, we have developed three lines of transgenic mice overexpressing mHGF using the rat insulin II promoter (RIP). Each RIP-HGF transgenic line displays clear expression of HGF mRNA and protein in the islet. RIP-mHGF mice are relatively hypoglycemic in post-prandial and fasting states compared with their normal littermates. They display inappropriate insulin production, striking overexpression of insulin mRNA in the islet, and a 2-fold increase in the insulin content in islet extracts. Importantly, beta cell replication rates in vivo are two to three times higher in RIP-HGF mice. This increase in proliferation results in a 2–3-fold increase in islet mass. Moreover, the islet number per pancreatic area was also increased by approximately 50%. Finally, RIP-mHGF mice show a dramatically attenuated response to the diabetogenic effects of streptozotocin. We conclude that the overexpression of HGF in the islet increases beta cell proliferation, islet number, beta cell mass, and total insulin production in vivo. These combined effects result in mild hypoglycemia and resistance to the diabetogenic effects of streptozotocin. The active form of HGF is a disulfide-linked heterodimeric protein, which is composed of a 69-kDa α-chain and a 34-kDa β-chain, containing four kringle domains and a serine protease-like domain, respectively. Active HGF derives from an inactive single chain precursor that is processed and activated by proteolysis. In order to determine whether local overexpression of HGF in the islet could result in an increase in islet mass and/or function in vivo, we have developed a transgenic mouse model of HGF overexpression in the islet using the rat insulin II promoter (RIP). We found that overexpression of HGF in the islet induces mild hypoglycemia, inappropriate hyperinsulinemia, and an increase in islet mass, reflecting an increase both in the number of islets as well as in the proliferation of beta cells. Interestingly, RIP-HGF mice show a dramatically attenuated response to the diabetogenic effects of streptozotocin. These results suggest that HGF could be useful in strategies focused on increasing islet mass and function in diabetes. RIP-HGF mice were generated as described previously for the RIP-parathyroid hormone-related protein transgenic mouse (33.Vasavada R.C. Cavaliere C. D'Ercole A.J. Dann P. Burtis W.J. Madlener A.L. Zawalich K. Zawalich W. Philbrick W. Stewart A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1200-1206Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Briefly, the RIP-HGF transgene was constructed by placing a 2.2-kilobase murine HGF cDNA (generously provided by Dr. Jumpei Enami at Zenyaku Kogyo Co, Tokyo, Japan) downstream of a fragment of 650 bp of the RIP, and upstream of untranslated human growth hormone sequences containing transcriptional termination, polyadenylation, and splicing signals; the GH sequences are not translated (35.Wysolmerski J.J. Broadus A.E. Zhou J. Fuchs E. Milstone L.M. Philbrick W.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 1133-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). The 2.2-kilobase mHGF cDNA contained the entire coding region of murine HGF. The resulting linearized construct (5.1 kilobase) was isolated, purified, and then microinjected into the pronuclei of (C57B16 × SJL) F2 mouse ova. Potential founders were screened by polymerase chain reaction analysis of tail DNA using human growth hormone-specific primers designed from the human growth hormone gene sequences (36.Weir E.C. Philbrick W.M. Amling M. Neff L.A. Baron R. Broadus A.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10240-10245Crossref PubMed Scopus (398) Google Scholar). Polymerase chain reaction efficiency was assessed by coamplification of a fragment of the endogenous murine glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase gene (36.Weir E.C. Philbrick W.M. Amling M. Neff L.A. Baron R. Broadus A.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 10240-10245Crossref PubMed Scopus (398) Google Scholar). Transgenic lines with germ line integration of the transgene were propagated by breeding to CD-1 outbred mice. All of the studies described in this manuscript were performed on mice between 8 and 14 weeks of age. All studies were performed with the approval of, and in accordance with, guidelines established by the University of Pittsburgh Animal Care and Use Committee. Tissues were harvested from control and transgenic mice and immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen. Total RNA was then isolated using Trizol reagent (Life Technologies, Inc., Grand Island, NY) according to the manufacturer's instructions. RNase protection assay was performed as described previously (33.Vasavada R.C. Cavaliere C. D'Ercole A.J. Dann P. Burtis W.J. Madlener A.L. Zawalich K. Zawalich W. Philbrick W. Stewart A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1200-1206Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar), using four different cRNA probes, which protected: (i) a 467-bp band corresponding to a HindIII cDNA fragment of the mouse HGF gene, (ii) a 230-bp band corresponding to murine insulin sequences protected by a PstI-AvaI mouse insulin genomic fragment, (iii) a 103-bp fragment of a highly conserved region of the mouse cyclophilin gene spanning exons 1 and 2 (Ambion, Austin, TX), and (iv) a 115-bp band corresponding to a KpnI-XbaI cDNA fragment of the human 28 S rRNA gene (Ambion). Blood was obtained by retroorbital bleeding as described previously (33.Vasavada R.C. Cavaliere C. D'Ercole A.J. Dann P. Burtis W.J. Madlener A.L. Zawalich K. Zawalich W. Philbrick W. Stewart A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1200-1206Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Glucose was measured on whole blood using a Precision Q.I.D. glucometer (Medisense Inc., Bedford, MA). Plasma insulin levels were determined by radioimmunoassay using a kit purchased from Linco Research Inc. (St. Louis, MO). The detection limit of the assay is 0.02 ng/ml. Mouse islets were isolated from 8–14-week-old control and transgenic mice as described previously (37.Gotoh M. Maki T. Kiyoizumi T. Satomi S. Monaco A.P. Transplantation. 1985; 40: 437-438Crossref PubMed Scopus (536) Google Scholar). Protein extracts were prepared using the acid/ethanol method (38.Davalli A.M. Qgawa Y. Scaglia L. Wu Y.J. Hollister J. Bonner-Weir S. Weir G.C. Diabetes. 1995; 44: 104-111Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), with some modifications. Briefly, acid/ethanol (0.18m HCl in 70% ethanol) was added to aliquots of 25 to 50 islets, sonicated 15 s, and extracted at 4 °C for 24 h. Tubes were then centrifuged at 2500 rpm for 10 min at 4 °C, and the supernatant stored at −20 °C. After neutralization, the insulin content in the extracts was measured using the insulin radioimmunoassay as described above. Protein concentrations in the islet extracts were determined using the Bradford method. Insulin concentrations are expressed as a function of the amount of protein in the islet extract. Pancreata were removed, fixed overnight in 10% buffered formalin or Bouin's solution, and embedded in paraffin. Sections were obtained and stained with hematoxylin and eosin using standard techniques. Immunostaining for insulin, glucagon, pancreatic polypeptide, and somatostatin was performed as previously reported (33.Vasavada R.C. Cavaliere C. D'Ercole A.J. Dann P. Burtis W.J. Madlener A.L. Zawalich K. Zawalich W. Philbrick W. Stewart A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1200-1206Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). HGF was detected in pancreatic sections subjected to antigen retrieval by heating in citrate buffer (1.8 mm citric acid, pH 6.0, 8.2 mm sodium citrate) in a microwave oven at 750 W for 5 min. Subsequently, sections were immunostained with an affinity purified goat anti-human HGF polyclonal antibody (Santa Cruz) at a 1:50 dilution. Visualization of the staining was achieved using the species-appropriate avidin-biotin complex system as described previously (39.Soifer N.E. Van Why S.K. Ganz M.B. Kashgarian M. Seigel N.J. Stewart A.F. J. Clin. Invest. 1993; 92: 2850-2857Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Histomorphometric analysis on insulin-stained sections from normal and transgenic mice was performed as previously reported (40.Stewart A.F. Vignery A. Silvergate A. Ravin N.D. LiVolsi V. Broadus A.E. Baron R. J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1982; 55: 219-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar). Briefly, quantitation of islet number and islet volume as a function of pancreatic volume was performed in insulin-stained sections by using a Nikon (Nikon Inc., New York, NY) Labophot microscope coupled to an Osteotablet (Osteometrics, Atlanta GA) planimeter and analyzed with Osteomeasure software package (Osteometrics). Beta cell replication was determined by 5-bromo-2′-deoxyuridine (BrdUrd) incorporation as described previously (41.Montana E. Bonner-Weir S. Weir G.C. J. Clin. Invest. 1994; 93: 1577-1582Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar), with minor modifications. Briefly, transgenic and normal littermates were injected intraperitoneally with BrdUrd (Cell Proliferation Kit, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and sacrificed after 6 h. Pancreata were removed and immediately fixed in Bouin's solution for 6 h, and then embedded, sectioned, deparaffinized, and stained with anti-BrdUrd antibody (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), and with antibodies against glucagon, pancreatic polypeptide (BioGenex, San Ramon, CA), and somatostatin (Novocastra Laboratories, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom). After counterstaining with hematoxylin, the sections were counted in a blinded fashion. Islet cells which stained for BrdUrd but not glucagon, pancreatic polypeptide or somatostatin were considered BrdUrd positive beta cells. At least 1000 islet nuclei were counted per pancreas. The results are expressed as the percentage of BrdUrd-positive beta cell nuclei per total number of beta cell nuclei. RIP-HGF transgenic mice and their normal littermates were injected intraperitoneally with two doses of 75 mg/kg streptozotocin (STZ) (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IN) separated by 12–16 h. Tail blood glucoses were measured at baseline and after STZ injections at the time points shown in Fig. 9 with the Precision Q.I.D. glucometer. All results are expressed as mean ± S.D. Statistical analysis was performed using the unpaired Student's t test. Nine founder RIP-HGF transgenic mice were identified. Two of these were mosaics and failed to transmit the transgene to their progeny. One female founder died during her first pregnancy. Thus, six lines with germ line integration of the transgene were obtained, with a range of approximately two to 30 transgene copies. Murine HGF mRNA expression in the pancreas of the six transgenic lines was analyzed by RNase protection assay. Three mouse lines displayed high levels of transgene expression when compared with the other three lines or with the very low expression detected in the normal pancreas (Fig. 1). Prolonged (96 h) exposure was necessary to visualize the expression of endogenous murine HGF mRNA in normal pancreas. The three highest expressors, lines 48, 51, and 54 were bred separately from one another, but because of their similar phenotypes, data from these lines were pooled, except where indicated. To confirm that RIP-HGF mice also overexpress HGF at the protein level, we performed immunohistochemical analysis of HGF expression in the islet of normal and transgenic pancreas. As can be seen in Fig.2, HGF is overexpressed in the islet cells of transgenic mouse pancreas, compared with the level of staining detected in the islet of normal mice (Fig. 2). As can be seen in Fig.3 A, blood glucose concentrations were significantly lower in RIP-HGF mice in both non-fasting and 24-h fasting conditions compared with the glucose concentrations observed in normal mice. The values shown in Fig.3 A represent the mean of the three transgenic lines. Each of the three lines display hypoglycemia of comparable degree. Given the relative hypoglycemia in the RIP-HGF mice in both states, one would expect lower plasma insulin values in the transgenic mice compared with the controls. Surprisingly, in both fasting and non-fasting situations, the plasma insulin values were not lower in the RIP-HGF mice than in their normal siblings (Fig. 3 B). Moreover, the insulin/glucose ratio was significantly higher in the RIP-HGF mice than in normal in post-prandial conditions, and slightly (but not significantly) higher at the 24-h fasted state (Fig.3 C). Immunohistochemical analysis performed using antisera against insulin, glucagon, somatostatin, and pancreatic polypeptide is shown in Fig.4. The pattern of distribution and the intensity of staining of these peptides in the islet of RIP-HGF mice were normal. No distribution or quantitative differences were observed in the staining of these islet hormones between transgenics and their normal littermates. To determine the level of expression of insulin mRNA in the RIP-HGF mice, we performed RNase protection analysis of islet total RNA from these mice and their normal siblings. We found that the steady-state insulin mRNA levels were 4–7-fold higher in the three lines of RIP-HGF mice compared with the corresponding controls (Fig.5 A). To confirm the insulin overexpression, we determined the insulin content in islet extracts by radioimmunoassay. We found that the amount of insulin expressed as a function of total islet protein, an index of insulin expression per beta cell, in RIP-HGF mice was approximately two times higher than in normal littermates (Fig. 5 B). Histological examination of insulin-stained sections from normal and transgenic pancreas suggested that the islet size in RIP-HGF mice was increased compared with the size observed in the normal littermates (Fig. 6 A). To document whether the islet mass was increased, we performed a blinded systematic quantitative histomorphometric analysis of pancreatic sections obtained from normal and transgenic mice. We found that the islet volume per unit of pancreatic volume was increased 2–3-fold in the RIP-HGF mice as compared with their littermates (Fig.6 B). Importantly, no significant differences were observed in either the overall size or in the total pancreatic volume between normal and transgenic mice, indicating that the increase in islet volume in these pancreatic sections is not the result of the decrease in exocrine volume. In addition, the islet number expressed as a function of pancreatic area was also increased by 50% in RIP-HGF mice (Fig. 6 C). As shown in Fig. 6, B andC, these changes in islet volume and number were observed in each of the three transgenic lines. Together, these results suggest that the individual islet size is increased in the RIP-HGF mice. In vitro studies have suggested that HGF is a potent mitogen for fetal and adult human beta cells (14.Otonkoski T. Cirulli V. Beattie G.M. Mally M.I. Soto G. Rubin J.S. Hayek A. Endocrinology. 1996; 137: 3131-3139Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 19.Otonkoski T. Beattie G.M. Rubin J.S. Lopez A.D. Baird A. Hayek A. Diabetes. 1994; 43: 947-953Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar,20.Hayek A. Beattie G.M. Cirulli V. Lopez A.D. Ricordi C. Rubin J.S. Diabetes. 1995; 44: 1458-1460Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, the RIP-HGF mice display a dramatic increase in islet mass (Fig. 6). We therefore determined the pancreatic beta cell proliferation rate in vivo by measuring BrdUrd incorporation into the pancreatic beta cell nuclei of RIP-HGF mice and their normal littermates. As shown in Fig. 7, the beta cell replication rate was increased by a factor of 2.5 in RIP-HGF mice compared with normal siblings. This increase in the proliferation rate was observed in each of the three lines. This indicates that an increase in the islet beta cell proliferation rate is likely at least one of the mechanisms through which islet mass is increased in the RIP-HGF mice. To explore the possible therapeutic role of HGF in diabetes mellitus, we studied the response of RIP-HGF mice to experimental diabetes induced by the diabetogenic agent, STZ. RIP-HGF transgenic mice and normal littermates were injected intraperitoneally with a dose of STZ that induces prompt hyperglycemia in normal mice. As shown in Fig. 8, normal mice developed frank diabetes with the injection of STZ. Three weeks after the injection with STZ the blood glucose was 450 ± 46 mg/dl. In contrast, RIP-HGF showed an attenuated response to STZ, displaying mild hyperglycemia 3 weeks post-injection (211 ± 37 mg/dl). In the present study we have found that overexpression of HGF in the islet of transgenic mice induces an impressive increase in the islet mass, and is associated with mild, relative hypoglycemia and inappropriate hyperinsulinemia. These in vivo results extend previous in vitro findings suggesting that HGF is one of the most potent mitogens and insulinotropic agents for beta cells (14.Otonkoski T. Cirulli V. Beattie G.M. Endocrinology. 1996; 137: 3131-3139Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), it seems likely that HGF may play a paracrine and/or autocrine physiological role in the growth and development of the pancreatic islet. HGF is known to possess potent mitogenic, motogenic, and morphogenic properties in many different cell types (4.Zarnegar R. Michalopoulos G.K. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 1177-1180Crossref PubMed Scopus (553) Google Scholar, 5.Matsumoto K. Nakamura T. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1996; 119: 591-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (615) Google Scholar). Recently, it has also been demonstrated that HGF prevents cell death in normal renal epithelial cells and hepatocytes (42.Liu Y. Sun A.M. Dworkin L.D. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 246: 821-826Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 43.Kosai K. Matsumoto K. Nagata S. Tsujimoto Y. Nakamura T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 244: 683-690Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar). In fact, HGF induces Bcl-xL and BAG-1 overexpression, and enhances protection from apoptosis. In our study we have observed that RIP-HGF mice almost tripled their pancreatic islet mass compared with control littermates. This augmentation seems to be the result of both an increase in beta cell proliferation rate and an increase in the islet number per pancreas. However, inhibitory effects of HGF on the already low normal apoptotic rate in the beta cells in the adult pancreas (44.Scaglia L. Smith F.E. Bonner-Weir S. Endocrinology. 1995; 136: 5461-5468Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar) have not been excluded. Along these lines, RIP-HGF mice are more resistant to the development of streptozotocin-induced diabetes than their normal littermates. STZ is a diabetogenic drug that behaves as a DNA alkylating agent or as a nitric oxide donor (45.Eizirik D.L. Sandler S. Ahnstrom G. Welsh M. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1991; 42: 2275-2282Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 46.Turk J. Corbett J.A. Ramanadham S. Bohrer A. McDaniel M.L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 197: 1458-1464Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar) inducing DNA fragmentation in beta cells (47.Yamamoto H. Uchigata Y. Okamoto H. Nature. 1981; 294: 284-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar), an indication that these cells undergo apoptosis after the treatment with this drug. The anti-apoptotic properties and/or the mitogenic effects of HGF could contribute to this resistance to, or the attenuation of, the diabetogenic effects of STZ in RIP-HGF mice. Alternatively, one might argue that the dose selected of STZ was lethal to a fixed number of islet cells, and since RIP-HGF have more islet cells than their normal siblings, the residual population of functional islet cells in the RIP-HGF mice remained sufficient to prevent or attenuate the development of diabetes mellitus. Further studies will be required to clarify the mechanism responsible for this protective effect. In addition to an increase in the islet mass, the RIP-HGF mice also show a significant increase in the number of islets per pancreatic area. Otonkoski and collagues (22.Otonkoski T. Mally M.I. Hayek A. Diabetes. 1994; 43: 1164-1166Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have demonstrated that the culture of human fetal islet-like cell clusters with HGF leads to a dramatic increase in the expression of Reg, a protein expressed in the islet beta cells which may be involved in pancreatic islet growth and regeneration (48.Watanabe T. Yonemura Y. Yonekura H. Suzuki Y. Miyashita H. Sugiyama K. Moriizumi S. Unno M. Tanaka O. Kondo H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 3589-3592Crossref PubMed Scopus (235) Google Scholar). The increase in islet number in RIP-HGF mice could be also the result of a direct effect on the differentiation of ductal precursor cells into pancreatic endocrine cells. For example, a recent report demonstrates that HGF is able to block the differentiation of acinar/endocrine AR42J cells to acinar-like cells, and to promote their conversion into insulin-producing cells (23.Mashima H. Shibata H. Mine T. Kojima I. Endocrinology. 1996; 137: 3969-3976Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). Also, Otonkoski et al. (19.Otonkoski T. Beattie G.M. Rubin J.S. Lopez A.D. Baird A. Hayek A. Diabetes. 1994; 43: 947-953Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar), have shown that HGF augments the formation of islet-like cell clusters in human fetal pancreatic tissue in culture. Taken together, these results suggest that HGF could act as a differentiation factor for the pancreatic islet and may promote islet neogenesis. RIP-HGF mice also display mild, relative hypoglycemia that appears to result from inappropriate hyperinsulinemia. Evidence for inappropriate hyperinsulinemia includes the failure of circulating insulin to suppress with hypoglycemia and the near-doubling of islet insulin content in the islet extracts from RIP-HGF mice. A possible mechanism responsible of this inappropriate hyperinsulinemia could be the result of random insertional events relating to the location of the transgene in the mouse genome. It is unlikely that this is the case since three independent transgenic lines expressing similar levels of HGF exhibited the same phenotype. It seems that the resulting hypoglycemia and inappropriate hyperinsulinemia appear to be specifically related to the expression of HGF in the pancreatic islet. This expression was accompanied by an increase in the levels of insulin mRNA and insulin peptide content in the islet. In addition, the pattern and intensity of staining for glucagon, somatostatin, or pancreatic polypeptide in normal and transgenic mice were identical. The observed increase in islet mass would appear to be responsible for the inappropriate hyperinsulinemia and mild hypoglycemia in the RIP-HGF mice. Abnormalities in beta cell glucose sensing, insulin biosynthesis rate, or insulin secretion mechanism within the islet beta cell, directly or indirectly induced by HGF expression, may also contribute to the inappropriate hyperinsulinemia in the RIP-HGF mice. The disproportionate increments in insulin protein and insulin mRNA levels within the islet were particularly striking, and are unexplained. It may be that HGF interferes with insulin biosynthesis, and/or that some degree of de-differentiation of beta cells occurs with HGF overexpression. Alternatively, a trivial explanation may be that beta cells degranulate during islet isolation inducing a falsely low estimate of islet insulin content. From a practical standpoint the net result is that, in RIP-HGF mice, sufficient quantities of insulin are produced to induce hypoglycemia. The explanation for this insulin protein/mRNA dissonance is worthy of exploration, however, as it may represent an additional target for enhancing RIP-HGF islet insulin secretion. Further studies will need to be performed to clarify these issues. In summary, our studies indicate that HGF may play a physiological role as a regulator of islet cell growth and differentiation. The increase in islet mass induced by HGF overexpression in the islet beta cells, perhaps accompanied by additional functional changes within the beta cells, would appear to be responsible of the observed mild, relative hypoglycemia and inappropriate hyperinsulinemia. We conclude that HGF, as other islet growth factors such as parathyroid hormone-related protein and mPL-I, are good candidates for future strategies aimed at the treatment of diabetes mellitus. αA-Crystallin, a member of the small heat shock protein (sHsp) family, is a large multimeric protein composed of 30–40 identical subunits. Its quaternary structure is highly dynamic, with subunits capable of freely and rapidly exchanging between oligomers. We report here the development of a fluorescence resonance energy transfer method for measuring structural compatibility between αA-crystallin and other proteins. We found that Hsp27 and αB-crystallin readily exchanged with fluorescence-labeled αA-crystallin, but not with other proteins structurally unrelated to sHsps. Truncation of 19 residues from the N terminus or 10 residues from the C terminus of αA-crystallin did not significantly change its subunit organization or exchange rate constant. In contrast, removal of the first 56 or more residues converts αA-crystallin into a predominantly small multimeric form consisting of three or four subunits, with a concomitant loss of exchange activity. These findings suggest residues 20–56 are essential for the formation of large oligomers and the exchange of subunits. Similar results were obtained with truncated Hsp27 lacking the first 87 residues. We further showed that the exchange rate is independent of αA-crystallin concentration, suggesting subunit dissociation may be the rate-limiting step in the exchange reaction. Our findings reveal a quarternary structure of αA-crystallin, consisting of small multimers of αA-crystallin subunits in a dynamic equilibrium with the oligomeric complex. αA-Crystallin, a member of the small heat shock protein (sHsp) family, is a large multimeric protein composed of 30–40 identical subunits. Using fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) to monitor subunit-subunit interaction, we have previously shown that the subunits of αA-crystallin can freely and reversibly exchange between oligomers (67.Bova M.P. Ding L.L. Horwitz J. Fung B.K.-K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29511-29517Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar). In this study we further demonstrate by this method that αA-crystallin can form a reversible hetero-oligomeric complex with Hsp27 and αB-crystallin, but not with other proteins unrelated to the sHsp family. In addition, we have identified the N-terminal region of αA-crystallin and Hsp27 to be essential for subunit exchange and oligomerization. Based on the results of our studies, we further propose an exchange mechanism that may explain the oligomeric organization of αA-crystallin subunits.DISCUSSIONIn this study we have developed a method to monitor the formation of hetero-oligomeric complexes between αA-crystallin and other structurally compatible proteins. Our method is based on the observed decrease in FRET between AIAS-labeled and LYI-labeled αA-crystallin upon the integration of a foreign protein into the oligomer. We found that the subunits of Hsp27 and αB-crystallin readily exchanged with αA-crystallin (Figs. 3 and 8), suggesting that their quaternary structures are compatible. In contrast, proteins that are not members of the sHsp family, such as β-crystallin, γ-crystallin, and rhodanese, were unable to integrate into the αA-crystallin oligomeric complex. β-Crystallin and γ-crystallin are composed of predominantly β-pleated sheets (8.Jaffe N.S. Horwitz J. Lens and Cataract. Gower Medical Publishing, 1991Google Scholar). While γ-crystallin is a monomer, β-crystallin can exist in multimeric forms (8.Jaffe N.S. Horwitz J. Lens and Cataract. Gower Medical Publishing, 1991Google Scholar). The absence of interaction between αA-crystallin and these proteins indicates that subunit exchange is not a property of any multimeric β-pleated sheet proteins.Our study indicated that the formation of a hetero-oligomeric complex between various forms of sHsp is not only feasible, but is probably quite common. What then is the importance of this type of hetero-oligomeric complex in vivo? α-Crystallin is composed of a 3:1 ratio of αA-crystallin to αB-crystallin in human lens. It has been shown that this complex has greater thermal stability than either protein alone (72.Sun T.X. Liang J.J.N. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 286-290Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Thus, one potentially important function of hetero-oligomers is the enhanced effectiveness in protecting cells from damage and stress. This is of paramount importance in the lens, where the lens proteins are constantly subjected to UV light, oxidative stress, and other external insults. Interestingly, Hsp27 is also expressed in the lens (15.Klemenz R. Andres A.C. Frohli E. Schafer R. Aoyama A. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 639-645Crossref PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). It would be interesting to find out whether or not it also forms a complex with α-crystallins and further contributes to the overall stability of these lens proteins.Hetero-oligomers containing αB-crystallin and Hsp27 have also been shown to be present in non-oncogenic adenovirus-transformed rat kidney cells and in human pectoral muscle (73.Zantema A. de Jong E. Chem. 1992; 267: 7718-7725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, contrary to the increased thermal stability observed in α-crystallin, the hetero-oligomer of αB-crystallin and Hsp27 was disrupted when cells were treated at 44 °C for 12 min (75.Zantema A. Verlaan-De Vries M. Maasdam D. Bol S. van der Eb A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 12936-12941Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We found that heat treatment at 44 °C did not dissociate the preformed complex of recombinant αA-crystallin and Hsp27 (data not shown), suggesting other cellular mechanisms such as phosphorylation or interaction with other proteins may modulate the dissociation of the Hsp27-αB-crystallin complex when the cell is under stress conditions.A hallmark of α-crystallin and other sHsp is their tendency to form large oligomeric structures. The organization of αA-crystallin subunits into larger oligomers most likely involves both ionic and hydrophobic interactions, since we have observed a decrease in the exchange rate under either very low salt or very high salt conditions (67.Bova M.P. Ding L.L. Horwitz J. Fung B.K.-K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29511-29517Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar). Most sHsp contain a stretch of relatively homologous sequence of approximately 100 residues termed the “α-crystallin domain.” This region has been postulated to mediate subunit-subunit interaction (83.Berengian A.R. Bova M.P. Mchaourab H.S. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9951-9957Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Recently, the structure of a 16.5-kDa sHsp from Methanococcus jannaschii has been determined at 2.9-Å resolution (84.Kim K.K. Kim R. Kim S-H Nature. 1998; 394: 595-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (783) Google Scholar). The oligomer was shown to be composed of 24 subunits, with each subunit in the complex making extensive contacts with other subunits through hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic contacts, and ionic interactions. Most of the contact sites are located within the α-crystallin domain, which consists primarily of anti-parallel β-strands. Similarly, a β-sheet structure consisting of three anti-parallel β-strands has also been identified in the same region of αA-crystallin and Hsp27 by site-directed spin-labeling (85.Koteiche H.A. Berengian A.R. Mchaourab H.S. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 12681-12688Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 86.Mchaourab H.S. Berengian A.R. Koteiche H.A. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14627-14634Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Moreover, residues 109–120 of αA-crystallin and 133–144 of Hsp27 have been shown to form contacts between equivalent strands from neighboring subunits (83.Berengian A.R. Bova M.P. Mchaourab H.S. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9951-9957Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar, 86.Mchaourab H.S. Berengian A.R. Koteiche H.A. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14627-14634Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Taken together, these recent findings suggest that some of the residues within the α-crystallin domain participate in subunit-subunit interaction. Perhaps these contact sites are also involved in stabilizing the quaternary structure of the small multimers.Our findings further suggest that the exchange unit of αA-crystallin are capable of freely associating and dissociating to form large oligomeric complexes. There are two potential mechanisms for the observed exchange reaction. The first mechanism involves the interchanging of the exchange unit as a result of collision between oligomers. The second mechanism is based on the continuous dissociation and reassociation of the exchange unit. Our data indicated that the transfer rate constant is independent of αA-crystallin concentration (Figs. 1 and 2), implying that the exchange of subunits is not due to the collision of the oligomers, but is most likely by a dissociation mechanism. If this mechanism is correct and the dissociation of the exchange unit is rate-limiting, as implied by the high activation energy of 60 kcal/mol (67.Bova M.P. Ding L.L. Horwitz J. Fung B.K.-K. J. We have obtained ak off value of 6.3 × 10−4s−1 under this condition. Interestingly, the dissociation rate constants of many biological processes, such as receptor binding (87.Jansson M. Uhlen M. Our truncation study further suggests that the N-terminal one-third of the Hsp27 molecule also contains the structure essential for subunit exchange activity (Figs. 6 and 9). Sequence comparison between αA-crystallin, Hsp27, and other members of the sHsp family indicates residues 18–28 and 40–46 of αA-crystallin are highly conserved. It is tempting to speculate that these residues may form an integral part of a common structural surface that allows unrestricted interfacing between various forms of sHsp. Pantothenate kinase (PanK) is the key regulatory enzyme in the CoA biosynthetic pathway in bacteria and is thought to play a similar role in mammalian cells. We examined this hypothesis by identifying and characterizing two murine cDNAs that encoded PanK. The two cDNAs were predicted to arise from alternate splicing of the same gene to yield different mRNAs that encode two isoforms (mPanK1α and mPanK1β) with distinct amino termini. The predicted protein sequence of mPanK1 was not related to bacterial PanK but exhibited significant similarity to Aspergillus nidulansPanK. mPanK1α was most highly expressed in heart and kidney, whereas mPanK1β mRNA was detected primarily in liver and kidney. Pantothenate was the most abundant pathway component (42.8%) in normal cells providing clear evidence that pantothenate phosphorylation was a rate-controlling step in CoA biosynthesis. Enhanced mPanK1β expression eliminated the intracellular pantothenate pool and triggered a 13-fold increase in intracellular CoA content. mPanK1β activityin vitro was stimulated by CoA and strongly inhibited by acetyl-CoA illustrating that differential modulation of mPanK1β activity by pathway end products also contributed to the management of CoA levels. These data support the concept that the expression and/or activity of PanK is a determining factor in the physiological regulation of the intracellular CoA concentration. These data support the concept that the expression and/or activity of PanK is a determining factor in the physiological regulation of the intracellular CoA concentration. pantothenate kinase coenzyme A, mPanK1, murine pantothenate kinase A. nidulans pantothenate kinase S. cerevisiae pantothenate kinase E. coli(bacterial) pantothenate kinase polymerase chain reaction expressed sequence-tagged base pair kilobase pair Pantothenate kinase (PanK)1(ATP:d-pantothenate 4′-phosphotransferase, EC 2.7.1.33) catalyzes the first committed step in the universal biosynthetic pathway leading to CoA (for review see Ref. 1.Jackowski S. Neidhardt F.C. Curtiss R. Gross C.A. Ingraham J.L. Lin E.C.C. Low K.B. Magasanik B. Reznikoff W. Riley M. Schaechter M. Umbarger H.E. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium: Cellular and Molecular Biology. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1996: 687-694Google Scholar). Phosphopantothenate is rapidly metabolized to CoA, which participates as an acyl group carrier in the tricarboxylic acid cycle, fatty acid metabolism, and numerous other reactions of intermediary metabolism (2.Abiko Y. Greenburg D.M. Metabolic Pathways. Academic Press, Inc., New York1975: 1-25Google Scholar). The 4′-phosphopantetheine portion of CoA is an essential prosthetic group in a number of enzyme systems including the acyl carrier protein components, bacterial and eukaryotic fatty acid synthases (3.Vagelos P.R. Curr. Top. Cell Regul. 1971; 4: 119-167Crossref Scopus (44) Google Scholar), citrate lyase (4.Dimroth P. Eur. J. Biochem. 1976; 64: 269-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), ferrichrome synthetase from Apsergillus quadricinctus (5.Siegmund K.D. Plattner H.J. Diekmann H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1076: 123-129Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar), and malonate decarboxylase of Malonomonas rubra (6.Dimroth P. Hilbi H. Mol. Microbiol. 1998; 25: 3-10Crossref Scopus (40) Google Scholar). PanK is the rate-controlling enzyme in CoA biosynthesis inEscherichia coli (1.Jackowski S. Neidhardt F.C. Curtiss R. Gross C.A. Ingraham J.L. Lin E.C.C. Low K.B. Magasanik B. Reznikoff W. Riley M. Schaechter M. Umbarger H.E. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium: Cellular and Molecular Biology. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1996: 687-694Google Scholar). E. coli is capable ofde novo pantothenate biosynthesis, and additionally a sodium-dependent permease actively transports exogenous pantothenate into the cell (7.Vallari D.S. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1985; 162: 1156-1161Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 8.Vallari D.S. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1985; 164: 136-142Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9.Jackowski S. Alix J.-H. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 3842-3848Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Metabolic labeling experiments established that the utilization, rather than the supply of pantothenate, controls the level of CoA (10.Jackowski S. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1981; 148: 926-932Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). E. colimutants with temperature-sensitive PanK activity are also temperature-sensitive for CoA biosynthesis and growth (11.Vallari D.S. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1987; 169: 5795-5800Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The PanK gene of E. coli (coaA) was cloned by functional complementation of this mutant and was identical to a previously sequenced allele called rts (12.Song W.-J. Jackowski S. J. Bacteriol. 1992; 174: 1705-1706Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 13.Song W.-J. Jackowski S. J. Bacteriol. 1992; 174: 6411-6417Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14.Flamm J.A. Friesen J.D. Otsuka J.A. Gene (Amst.). 1988; 74: 555-558Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar). E. coliPanK (bPanK) is a homodimer of 36-kDa subunits that exhibit highly positive cooperative ATP binding and mediate sequential ordered catalysis with ATP as the leading substrate (15.Song W.-J. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27051-27058Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CoA and its thioesters inhibit bPanK activity by competitive binding to the ATP site (15.Song W.-J. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27051-27058Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16.Vallari D.S. Jackowski S. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 2468-2471Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Nonesterified CoA is the most potent inhibitor of bPanKin vitro and in vivo, whereas acetyl-CoA is about 20% as effective as CoA (16.Vallari D.S. Jackowski S. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 2468-2471Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This feedback regulation is a primary mechanism by which bacteria control the cellular CoA level. PanK is also proposed to be the master regulator of CoA biosynthesis in mammalian cells (for review see Ref. 17.Robishaw J.D. Neely J.R. Am. J. Physiol. 1985; 248: E1-E9Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Metabolic labeling experiments in the rat heart model support a role for PanK in controlling flux through the CoA biosynthetic pathway (18.Robishaw J.D. Berkich D.A. Neely J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10967-10972Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19.Robishaw J.D. Neely J.R. Am. J. Physiol. 1984; 246: H532-H541Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Since CoA and its thioesters are important regulators of several key enzymes in intermediary metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase, adjustments in the level of CoA and acetyl-CoA that occur in the examples cited above contribute to the metabolic alterations observed during fasting, in diabetes, and following treatment with hypolipidemic drugs. CoA and CoA thioesters also inhibit crude preparations of mammalian (18.Robishaw J.D. Berkich D.A. Neely J.R. J. Biol. (Tokyo). 1972; 71: 1065-1067Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 34.Fisher M.N. Neely J.R. FEBS Lett. 1985; 190: 293-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 35.Abiko Y. Ashida S. Shimizu M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1972; 268: 364-372Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar, 36.Halvorsen O. Tverdal S. Scand. J. Clin. Invest. Suppl. 1986; 184: 67-70PubMed Google Scholar) and plant (37.Falk K.L. Guerra D.J. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1993; 301: 424-430Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) PanK enzymes. In contrast to bacteria, acetyl-CoA is significantly more effective than CoA at inhibiting mammalian PanK in cell extracts and partially purified preparations. A recent detailed study with a purified eukaryotic PanK from A. nidulans (aPanK) found that acetyl-CoA was a potent aPanK inhibitor, whereas CoA was ineffective (38.Calder R.B. Williams R.S.B. Ramaswamy G. Rock C.O. Campbell E. Unkles S.E. Kinghorn J.R. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 2014-2020Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). The bacterial PanK and aPanK do not exhibit a significant degree of similarity in their protein sequences reflecting the sharp contrast in the specificity of feedback regulation between the two proteins. The goal of the present study was to identify and characterize a mammalian PanK and test whether the expression level of this enzyme influences the regulation of intracellular CoA content, and to determine if CoA or acetyl-CoA is the most important feedback regulator of mammalian PanK activity. Sources of supplies were as follows: American Radiolabeled Chemicals, d-[1-14C]pantothenate (specific activity, 53.5 mCi/mmol); Bio-Rad, Bradford dye-binding protein assay solution; Promega, Klenow fragment; Analtech Inc., 250-μm Silica Gel H thin layer chromatography plates; Qiagen, Qiaquick kit; NEN Life Science Products, [α-32P]dCTP (specific activity, 3000 Ci/mmol); Fisher, Scintisafe 30%; Life Technologies, Inc., LipofectAMINETM reagent; Promega, restriction endonucleases and T4 DNA ligase; Qiagen, P100 columns; Sigma, CoA, acetyl-CoA, and malonyl-CoA; and Whatman, DE81 filter circles. All other materials were reagent grade or better. The A. nidulansPanK sequence was used to search the EST data base for related clones. This yielded clone AA030321 expressed in fetal tissue that contains the common region of mPanK1. mPanK1α- (AA014914 expressed in mouse placenta) and mPanK1β-specific (AI181055 expressed in mouse liver andAA105778 expressed in mouse kidney) EST clones were subsequently identified using AA030321. 3′-Rapid amplification of cDNA ends was performed to determine the 3′-untranslated region of the mPanK1 cDNA using reagents supplied by Life Techologies, Inc. Poly(A)+ RNAs (0.2 μg) from mouse brain, heart, kidney, liver, or skeletal muscle tissues (CLONTECH) were used as template for the first-strand cDNA synthesis together with an oligo(dT)-containing adapter primer 5′-GGCCACGCGTCGACTAGTACTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT-3′ and Superscript TMII reverse transcriptase. The first-strand cDNA was used as a template for the PCR using the mPanK1-specific primer 5′-GATCTAGTGATCTTTTGGATCAAGG-3′ and the abridged universal amplification primer 5′-GGCCACGCGTCGACTAGTAC-3′. PCR products of the same size were amplified from all five tissues. The products were subcloned into the TA vector pCR2.1 (Invitrogen) and sequenced on both strands using M13 forward and reverse primers. The cDNA sequences of the 3′-untranslated regions were identical in all of the clones. The mPanK1β expression vector (pmPanK1β) was constructed by digesting EST clone AA105778 with BstXI. This product was first blunted by digestion with mung bean nuclease and the product was then digested with NheI. This fragment containing the entire mPanK1β open reading frame was cloned into plasmid pcDNA3.1 that had been digested with EcoRV and NheI. The clone was verified by DNA sequencing. The mPanK cDNA sequences were determined on both strands by automated DNA sequencing using ABI 373A automated fluorescent sequencing equipment at the Molecular Resource Center of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Enzyme preparation and assays were performed as described previously (16.Vallari D.S. Jackowski S. Rock C.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 2468-2471Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The pantothenate kinase-specific activities in cell lysates were calculated as a function of protein concentration. Assays were linear with respect to both time and protein input. Protein concentrations were measured by the method of Bradford (39.Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (217544) Google Scholar) with bovine γ-globulin as a standard. Standard assays containedd-[1-14C]pantothenate (45.5 μm; specific activity 55 mCi/mmol), ATP (2.5 mm, pH 7.0), MgCl2 (2.5 mm), Tris-HCl (0.1 m, pH 7.5), and 15 μg of protein from a soluble cell extract (see below) in a total volume of 40 μl. The mixture was incubated for 10 min at 37 °C, and the reaction was stopped by depositing a 30-μl aliquot onto a Whatman DE81 ion-exchange filter disc that was washed in three changes of 1% acetic acid in 95% ethanol (25 ml/disc) to remove unreacted pantothenate. 4′-Phosphopantothenate was quantitated by counting the dried disc in 3 ml of scintillation solution. COS-7 cells were grown in 100-mm dishes to 80% confluency in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% glutamine. Transfections using LipofectAMINETM reagent were performed according to the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, 10 μg of plasmid and 60 μl of LipofectAMINETM reagent were diluted separately into 0.8 ml of serum-free medium. The two solutions were combined and incubated at room temperature for 45 min. Next, 6.4 ml of serum-free medium was added to each tube, and the diluted solution was overlaid onto cells that had been previously rinsed with serum-free medium. The cells and reagents were incubated at 37 °C for 5 h and then 8 ml of growth medium containing twice the normal amount of serum was added. The medium was replaced 24 h after the start of the transfection procedure. At 24 h post-transfection, cells were labeled at 37 °C for 24 h with d-[1-14C]pantothenate (2 μm, specific activity 55 mCi/mmol) in pantothenate-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and dialyzed serum. Cells were washed with phosphate-buffered saline, harvested by scraping and centrifugation, and stored as pellets at −20 °C. Pantothenate metabolites were separated on Silica Gel H thin layers developed withn-butyl alcohol/acetic acid/water (5:2:3 v/v) and quantitated by zonal scraping of the plates followed by scintillation counting of the silica gel fractions. The identities of individual metabolites were confirmed by co-migration with standards in both the acidic chromatography system described above and a basic solvent system (ethanol/28% ammonium hydroxide, 4:1, v/v) as described previously (10.Jackowski S. Rock C.O. J. Bacteriol. 1981; 148: 926-932Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Panothenate kinase activity was measured in COS-7 cells that had been incubated for 48 h at 37 °C following transfection with plasmid pmPanK1β or pcDNA3.1 vector. Transfected cell pellets were resuspended in 100 μl of hypotonic lysis buffer (10 mmTris-Cl pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, 5 μg/ml leupeptin, 10 mm NaF) and left on ice for 30 min. Cells were then sonicated in a cup horn at maximum power three times for 30 s. Unbroken cells and cell debris were pelleted by centrifugation for 5 min at 5,000 × g. PanK activity was measured in aliquots of the cell extracts as described above. A mouse multiple tissue Northern blot was purchased from CLONTECH and hybridized and washed according to the manufacturer's instructions. The blot was first hybridized with an 808-bp 32P-labeled probe prepared from the digestion of cDNA clone AA030321 with AatII andNdeI which lies within the region common to both splice variants and which would signal the mRNAs encoding both mPanK1 isoforms. The mPanK1α-specific 171-bp probe was prepared by PCR amplification using the mPanK1α cDNA clone W83049 as a template and the 5′-GAACGGGCTGCTGCACAAC-3′ plus 5′-GTTCTTCCTCCCGGAGTCC-3′ primer pair. The 187-bp mPanK1β-specific probe was prepared by PCR amplification using the mPanK1β cDNA clone AI181055 as the template and the 5′-GGTAGACTGTAAAGGGTACC-3′ plus 5′-GCTTTCTGCCATTTACAAGC-3′ primer pair. RT-PCR was performed using mouse brain, heart, kidney, liver, or skeletal muscle poly(A)+ RNAs that were purchased fromCLONTECH. The RNAs (200 ng) were used as template to synthesize the first strand cDNA using Superscript TMII reverse transcriptase (Life Technologies, Inc.) following the manufacturer's recommended procedure and using the gene-specific primer 5′-CGTAGGCAGTGTTAGAAGTTAAATAC-3′ that was common to both mPanK1α and mPanK1β cDNAs. PCR amplification was carried out using 4 μl of the individual first-strand cDNAs as template together with a nested primer specific for the common region 5′-GCCGTGATATCCTTCGGTTC-3′ (R289) plus either the mPanK1α-specific primer 5′-GAACGGGCTGCTGCACAAC-3′ (F35) or the mPanK1β-specific primer 5′-GGTAGACTGTAAAGGGTACC-3′ (A16). PCR reactions were performed in 20 μl with 35 thermocycles at 94 °C for 30 s for denaturation, 55 °C for 1 min for annealing, and 72 °C for 2 min extension. PCR products (8 μl) were separated by gel electrophoresis in 1.4% agarose. BLAST searches of the public expressed sequence tagged (EST) data base identified cDNA clones (GenBankTM accession numbers AA030321 andAA014914 for mPanK1α; AI181055 and AA105778 for mPanK1β) with sequences homologous to the A. nidulans PanK (38.Calder R.B. Williams R.S.B. Ramaswamy G. Rock C.O. Campbell E. Unkles S.E. Kinghorn J.R. Jackowski S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 2014-2020Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar) (Fig.1). The clones were purchased, and the complete cDNA sequences were determined on both strands for each clone. Analysis of the sequence data revealed that the mRNAs were the products of the same gene, and the cDNAs were predicted to encode two protein isoforms, designated mPanK1α and mPanK1β. The open reading frame encoding mPanK1β was preceded by an in-frame stop codon upstream from the first methionine. An in-frame stop codon in the 5′-sequence of the mPanK1α cDNA was not found, leaving open the possibility that the entire open reading frame had not been identified. Thus efforts were focused on characterization of the mPanK1β cDNA. The mPanK1β cDNA was predicted to encode a protein of 373 amino acids. The predicted molecular size of mPanK1β was 41,642 Da with a predicted isoelectric point of 6.03. The predicted amino acid sequence of mPanK1α included a methionine that aligned with the assigned translational start site of the mPanK1β cDNA (Fig. 1). The amino terminus of the α isoform differed from the β isoform from residues 2 to 10. Both isoforms were identical in amino acid sequence and in length from residues 11 to 373. The results of 3′-rapid amplification of cDNA ends on five different murine tissue poly(A)+RNAs confirmed the presence of the polyadenylation signal (AATAAA) in the 3′-untranslated region followed by the poly(A)+ tail 22 bp downstream. These data confirmed the assignment of the stop codon after residue 373. The relative abundance of mPanK1 mRNA expression in a variety of adult mouse tissues was addressed by Northern blot analysis (Fig. 2). Each lane contained 2 μg of poly(A)+ RNA isolated from the tissues indicated, and the blot was probed first with radiolabeled cDNA representing the coding sequence common to both mPanK1β and mPanK1α. A 3.6-kb mRNA was detected at high levels in heart, liver, and kidney tissues, with lower levels in brain and skeletal muscle. A 3.1-kb mRNA was also detected at high levels in liver and kidney and to a lesser extent in testis. A larger RNA of approximately 5 kb was also signaled in liver. Radiolabeled probes specific for either the mPanK1α or the mPanK1β coding sequences were then hybridized sequentially to kidney poly(A)+ mRNA because this tissue expressed both mPanK1 mRNAs. These experiments revealed that the 3.6-kb mRNA corresponded to mPanK1α expression, whereas the smaller 3.1-kb mRNA corresponded to mPanK1β expression (Fig. 2). To verify the results obtained with the Northern blotting, RT-PCR was performed using poly(A)+ RNA isolated from various mouse tissues as template for the RT reaction. Isoform-specific primers corresponding to the 5′-ends of either the α or β cDNAs were paired with a primer corresponding to the mPanK1 common sequence in the PCR step. The mPanK1β message was confirmed to be in abundance in kidney and liver, whereas brain, heart, and skeletal muscle were found to express mPanK1β at a lower, but detectable, level (Fig.3). The mPanK1α message was confirmed to be at high levels in heart, kidney, and liver, less in brain, and then at low but detectable levels in skeletal muscle (Fig. 3). These results were consistent with the conclusions derived from the Northern blot, where mPanK1α and mPanK1β mRNAs were abundant and present at about the same steady-state levels in kidney; mPanK1β expression was greater than mPanK1α in liver, and heart expressed primarily mPanK1α. The enhanced sensitivity of RT-PCR enabled detection of relatively low expression of the two isoforms in skeletal muscle and in brain, where the expression of mPanK1α was slightly greater than that of mPanK1β (Figs. 2 and 3).Figure 3RT-PCR analysis of mPanK1α and mPanK1β expression in mouse tissues. A, tissue distribution of mPanK1α evaluated using the F35 and R289 primer pair. B, tissue distribution of mPanK1β determined using the A16 and R289 primer pair. Primer R289 was a reverse primer from the common region of both mPanK1 cDNAs, whereas primer F35 was specific for the mPanK1α transcript, and A16 was specific for the mPanK1β transcript. C, control RT-PCR experiments: lane 1, primer F35 + template; lane 2, primer R289 + template; lane 3, primer A16 + template; lane 4, A16 + R289 without template. Details of the primers and PCR conditions are described under “Experimental Procedures.”View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) COS-7 cells were transfected with the expression plasmid pmPanK1β or pcDNA3.1 vector control, and 48 h later cell lysates were prepared. Pantothenate kinase enzymatic activity was significantly higher in the lysate from pmPanK1β-transfected cells (Fig.4). Endogenous pantothenate kinase was detected in the control lysates at protein concentrations of 50 μg and higher (data not shown) with an average specific activity of 3.24 ± 0.07 pmol/min/mg. In the experiment shown in Fig. 4, pantothenate kinase enzyme was overexpressed an estimated 250 times in the cells transfected with pmPanK1β, indicating that a functional protein was encoded by the plasmid. Repeated transfections with the plasmid construct gave similar results. Two sets of COS-7 cells were transfected with either the mPanK1β expression plasmid or the control vector. Cells within a set were pooled and re-plated into pantothenate-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium plus dialyzed serum 24 h after transfection to avoid variation in transfection efficiency among replicate dishes.d-[1-14C]Pantothenate (2 μm) was added, and cells were radiolabeled for another 24 h at 37 °C and then harvested. Overexpression of mPanK1β was 919.9 ± 13.2 pmol/min/mg as determined by biochemical assay of an aliquot of the pooled cells from each set. The relative amounts of cellular pantothenate and its metabolites were compared in control cells and in cells overexpressing mPanK1β (Fig. 5). Pantothenate, which is the substrate for pantothenate kinase, constituted 43% of the total radiolabeled metabolite pool in control cells, whereas the product of the kinase, phosphopantothenate, was not detectable (Fig. 5 A). These data indicated that the phosphorylation of pantothenate by the endogenous level of PanK was rate-limiting to the CoA biosynthetic pathway and was consistent with previous results obtained in bacteria (1.Jackowski S. Neidhardt F.C. Curtiss R. Gross C.A. Ingraham J.L. Lin E.C.C. Low K.B. Magasanik B. Reznikoff W. Riley M. Schaechter M. Umbarger H.E. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium: Cellular and Molecular Biology. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1996: 687-694Google Scholar) and mammals (18.Robishaw J.D. Berkich D.A. Neely J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10967-10972Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19.Robishaw J.D. Neely J.R. Am. J. Physiol. 1984; 246: H532-H541Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The data also demonstrated that the transport of pantothenate into the cell was not limiting, but rather cellular pantothenate accumulated prior to its phosphorylation by PanK. Neither 4′-phosphopantothenate nor 4′-phosphopantothenoylcysteine was detected, but phosphopantetheine was the second most abundant metabolite and constituted 35% of the total (Fig. 5 A). These data suggested that the phosphopantetheine adenylyltransferase also catalyzed a slow step in the CoA biosynthetic pathway. The adenylyltransferase is three steps removed from PanK and converts 4′-phosphopantetheine into dephospho-CoA by addition of an adenine moiety. CoA was the third metabolite that was present in significant amounts, and it represented 22% of the total radiolabeled material (Fig. 5 A), the smallest of the three major pools in the control cells. In contrast, cells overexpressing mPanK1β did not accumulate pantothenate but readily metabolized it (Fig. 5 B and Fig.6). The total uptake ofd-[1-14C]pantothenate also increased by about 4-fold in response to overexpression of mPanK1β (Fig. 6). The cellular radiolabeled pool was dominated by two metabolites, CoA (75%) and 4′-phosphopantetheine (25%). The CoA level was 13 times higher in cells with the PanK construct and, unlike in control cells, exceeded the level of 4′-phosphopantetheine. These data demonstrated that the expression level of PanK1β influenced both the uptake and metabolism of pantothenate and, most importantly, regulated the cellular CoA content. The data also indicated that whereas the phosphopantetheine adenylyltransferase may be a slow step in the pathway of CoA biosynthesis, possible regulation at this step was secondary to regulation by the PanK enzyme. The potato tuber (Solanum tuberosumL.) ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (ADP-GlcPPase) catalyzes the first committed step in starch biosynthesis. The main type of regulation of this enzyme is allosteric, and its activity is controlled by the ratio of activator, 3-phosphoglycerate to inhibitor, Pi. It was reported (Fu, Y., Ballicora, M. A., Leykam, J. F., and Preiss, J. (1998) J. Biol. Chem. 273, 25045–25052) that the enzyme was activated by reduction of the Cys12disulfide linkage present in the catalytic subunits. In this study, both reduced thioredoxin f and m from spinach (Spinacia oleracea) leaves reduced and activated the enzyme at low concentrations (10 μm) of activator (3-phosphoglycerate). Fifty percent activation was at 4.5 and 8.7 μm for reduced thioredoxin f andm, respectively, and 2 orders of magnitude lower than for dithiothreitol. The activation was reversed by oxidized thioredoxin. Cys12 is conserved in the ADP-GlcPPases from plant leaves and other tissues except for the monocot endosperm enzymes. We postulate that in photosynthetic tissues, reduction could play a role in the fine regulation of the ADP-GlcPPase mediated by the ferredoxin-thioredoxin system. This is the first time that a covalent mechanism of regulation is postulated in the synthesis of starch. The potato tuber (Solanum tuberosumL.) This is the first time that a covalent mechanism of regulation is postulated in the synthesis of starch. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1984; 38: 419-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (278) Google Scholar, 2.Preiss J. Preiss J. The Biochemistry of Plants. 14. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1988: 181-254Crossref Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 3.Preiss J. Foyer C. Quick P. Engineering Improved Carbon and Nitrogen Resource Use Efficiency in Higher Plants. Plenum Publishing Corp., New York1998: 177-223Crossref Scopus (60) Google Scholar). In vitro, since the reaction is reversible, the enzyme also catalyzes the pyrophosphorolysis of the ADP-Glc to produce ATP and Glc-1-P. The potato (Solanum tuberosum) tuber enzyme, as all the ADP-GlcPPases from higher plants studied so far, is a heterotetramer comprised of two distinct subunits (5.Okita T.W. Nakata P.A. Anderson J.M. Sowokinos J. Morell M. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1990; 93: 785-790Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Both of these genes were cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli to yield a recombinant enzyme comprised of two large (51 kDa) subunits and two small (50 kDa) subunits (L2S2) (3.Preiss J. Foyer C. Quick P. Engineering Improved Carbon and Nitrogen Resource Use Efficiency in Higher Plants. Taylor & Francis Ltd., London1997: 81-104Google Scholar, 6.Ballicora M.A. Laughlin M.J. Fu Y. Okita T.W. Barry G.F. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1995; 109: 245-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). The amino acid sequence of the small subunits of higher plant ADP-GlcPPases is highly conserved, but the similarity among different large subunits is lower (7.Smith-White B.J. Preiss J. J. Mol. Evol. 1992; 34: 449-464Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). The major function of the large subunit is to modulate the regulatory properties of the small subunit, which is primarily involved in catalysis (6.Ballicora M.A. Laughlin M.J. Fu Y. Okita T.W. Barry G.F. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1995; 109: 245-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 8.Ballicora M.A. Fu Y. Nesbitt N.M. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1998; 118: 265-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 9.Fu Y. Ballicora M.A. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1998; 117: 989-996Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). In every plant tissue studied so far, the major activator of the enzyme is 3-phosphoglycerate (3-PGA) and the major inhibitor is orthophosphate (Pi) (2.Preiss J. Preiss J. The Biochemistry of Plants. 14. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1988: 181-254Crossref Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 10.Preiss J. Annu. Rev. Plant. Physiol. 1982; 33: 431-454Crossref Google Scholar). In photosynthetic organisms, the ratio [3-PGA]/[Pi] regulates allosterically this reaction and therefore the synthesis of starch (10.Preiss J. Annu. Rev. Plant. Physiol. 1982; 33: 431-454Crossref Google Scholar). It was found that the activity of both the recombinant and the ADP-GlcPPase purified from potato tubers is stimulated by dithiothreitol (DTT) (6.Ballicora M.A. Laughlin M.J. Fu Y. Okita T.W. Barry G.F. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1995; 109: 245-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 11.Sowokinos J.R. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1981; 68: 924-929Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, it was possible to characterize with the recombinant enzyme the mechanism of this stimulation (12.Fu Y. Ballicora M.A. Leykam J.F. Preiss J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25045-25052Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). There are two distinct stages, activation and catalysis (Scheme FSI). The first one is a slow step that involves DTT and the substrates to convert the enzyme from a native (oxidized) to an activated reduced form. DTT is responsible for the reduction of the only disulfide bond present in the oxidized form, which is an intermolecular bridge between Cys12 of the two small subunits. The substrates are needed to attain the active conformation after the reduction. This process was tested in the absence of activators and inhibitors in the catalytic step. The ratio [3-PGA]/[Pi] is, however, still the main factor to regulate the activity of the enzyme. The reductive activation by DTT increased the activity up to 4-fold (12.Fu Y. Ballicora M.A. Leykam J.F. Preiss J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25045-25052Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar), whereas 3-PGA activated the enzyme 30-fold (8.Ballicora M.A. Fu Y. Nesbitt N.M. Preiss J. Plant Physiol. (Bethesda). 1998; 118: 265-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The Cys12 is conserved in all small subunits from plant ADP-GlcPPases known so far with the exception of the ones from endosperm tissue. The role of the activation by DTT was not clear since it is not a physiological compound. However, the regulation of many enzymes in plants follows a similar scheme of activation, as depicted in Scheme FSI, where the physiological reductant is thioredoxin. In this study, we tested both thioredoxin m and ffrom spinach (Spinacia oleracea) leaves. We observed that their reduced forms are able to activate the ADP-GlcPPase from potato tuber 4-fold when assayed at low concentrations of 3-PGA. We postulate that thioredoxin could play a role as a fine regulator of the ADP-GlcPPase from potato and from other plant tissues having the conserved Cys on the N-terminal of the small subunit. The reaction was started by the addition of the enzyme and, after 2 min incubation at 37 °C, was terminated by the addition of 3 ml of cold 5% trichloroacetic acid. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 252: 274-283Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). Purified thioredoxins were incubated 5 min at 37 °C in the presence of 50 mm Hepes (pH 8.0), 0.1 mm EDTA, and 5 mm of either reduced or oxidized DTT. 50 μl of this reaction was desalted with Bio-spin 6TM columns (Bio-Rad) equilibrated in 50 mm Hepes (pH 8.0) and used immediately. An aliquot of the eluate was separated and diluted in a 50-μl quartz cuvette to measure the concentration of thioredoxin as mentioned above. This procedure efficiently removed the DTT from the samples. A control with reduced DTT but no thioredoxin showed no detectable amounts of DTT after the desalting step (<4 μm) using 5,5′-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) as described above. Kinetic data were plotted as velocity versussubstrate or effector concentration. Kinetic constants were obtained by nonlinear least square fitting of the data with the Hill equation using the program OriginTM 5.0 (Microcal Software Inc., Northampton, MA). Kinetic constants were expressed asA 0.5, S 0.5,I 0.5, which correspond to the concentration of effector necessary to reach 50% of maximal activation, velocity, and inhibition, respectively. The Hill coefficient was represented asn. The ADP-GlcPPase from potato tuber was sensitive to reduction by both of the reduced thioredoxins tested. It has been shown that the small subunit of the potato tuber ADP-GlcPPase migrates as a dimer in non-reducing SDS-PAGE when the intersubunit disulfide bridge Cys12-Cys12 is present (oxidized form) and as monomer when it is cleaved (reduced form) (12.Fu Y. Ballicora M.A. Leykam J.F. Preiss J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25045-25052Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). The large subunit, which has no disulfide bridge, runs in both conditions as a monomer (12.Fu Y. Ballicora M.A. Leykam J.F. Preiss J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25045-25052Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). Therefore, a change of the redox state of the heterotetrameric enzyme can be detected clearly from a modification of the electrophoretic mobility of the small subunit. The antibody (anti-spinach leaf ADP-GlcPPase) used in this work to develop the immunoblot after the electrophoresis is more reactive against the small subunit than the large subunit from potato tuber ADP-GlcPPase. When the enzyme was incubated for 15 min in the presence of ADP-Glc, Mg2+, and either thioredoxin f or m, changes in the electrophoretic mobility were observed (Fig.1). The lower band, which corresponds to the monomers, was much stronger after the incubation, whereas the upper band that constitutes the dimer of the small subunit almost disappeared. When the enzyme was incubated with oxidized thioredoxin, no significant difference was observed with respect to the control. This indicates that the reduced form of both thioredoxins were responsible for the change of mobility of the ADP-GlcPPase, which is attributable to the reduction of the enzyme. Concurrently, these changes in the redox state of the ADP-GlcPPase correlated with the activity in the pyrophosphorolysis direction. When the enzyme was reduced by either thioredoxin, the activity increased more than 2-fold when assayed in absence of the allosteric activator 3-PGA (Fig. 1). Since the reduced thioredoxins f andm can activate the enzyme in the pyrophosphorolysis direction, it was of interest to test the properties of the reduced and oxidized forms of the ADP-GlcPPase in the ADP-Glc synthesis direction, which is the physiological reaction. Once the enzyme was reduced in presence of thioredoxin f, the activity was assayed at different concentrations of 3-PGA and compared with the enzyme treated in absence of thioredoxin (control). It was observed that the thioredoxin-reduced ADP-GlcPPase has a higher affinity for the activator (Fig. 2). TheA 0.5 was 40 μm for the reduced and 85 μm for the control enzyme. Since the curve of the control enzyme was slightly more sigmoidal (n = 1.5) than the curve of the activated enzyme (n = 0.8), the activity at lower concentrations of activator was markedly higher for the thioredoxin-reduced ADP-GlcPPase. When the concentration of 3-PGA was 10 μm in the assay mixture, the activity of the thioredoxin-reduced enzyme was more than 4-fold higher than the control. However, both of the forms of the ADP-GlcPPase, reduced and oxidized, did not show big differences in the parameters of other effectors: the main inhibitor (Pi), substrate (Glc-1-P) and the cofactor (Mg2+) (TableI). Only the substrate ATP showed a significant but rather small difference since the apparent affinity of the reduced form was 1.6-fold higher (Table I). TheS 0.5 values were 56 and 90 μm for the reduced and oxidized forms, respectively. In presence of Pi, there is a shift on both 3-PGA activation curves, but the effect of the thioredoxin is maintained. The reversibility of the process was examined incubating the activated (reduced) ADP-GlcPPase in the presence of oxidized thioredoxin. This inactivation was completely reversible because after the addition of DTT the activity increased 4.2-fold (Table II), which is the ratio that is expected between the oxidized and reduced form (Figs. 3 and 4).
